video.title: Automate with Python – Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn how to automate your life with Python! You will learn how to automate boring and repetitive tasks such as creating an Excel report, sending text messages, extracting tables from websites, interacting with websites, and more. You will learn how to use a few different Python libraries to help with automation such as Path, Selenium, XPath, and more.

💻 Source Code & Datasets: https://github.com/ifrankandrade/automation

✏️ Course from Frank Andrade. Check out his YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/FrankAndrade5
🔗 Automation Cheat Sheet: https://frankandrade.ck.page/44559e1ae7
🔗 Frank's 11-Hour Automation Course in Python: https://www.udemy.com/course/automate-your-life-with-python/?referralCode=7FA8B361D7A92B03A8C3
🔗 Frank's Discord Server: https://discord.gg/6xyQaj8bJK

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:00:31) Project #1 Table Extraction - Extract Tables from Websites
⌨️ (0:02:53) Table Extraction - Extract CSV Files from Websites
⌨️ (0:09:38) Table Extraction - Extract Tables from PDFs
⌨️ (0:13:06) Project #2 - Web Automation & Web Scraping - HTML Basics - Tags and Elements
⌨️ (0:20:57) Web Automation & Web Scraping - HTML Basics - Tree Structure
⌨️ (0:24:22) Web Automation & Web Scraping - XPath - Syntax, Functions and Operators
⌨️ (0:28:06) Web Automation & Web Scraping - XPath - Test Your XPath
⌨️ (0:33:38) Web Automation & Web Scraping - XPath - Special Characters and Syntax
⌨️ (0:38:17) Automate The News - Installing Selenium and ChromeDriver
⌨️ (0:40:34) Automate The News - Creating The Driver
⌨️ (0:44:46) Automate The News - Finding Elements
⌨️ (1:04:34) Automate The News - Exporting Data to a CSV File
⌨️ (1:12:34) Automate The News - Headless mode
⌨️ (1:18:18) Automate The News - Preparing Script to Be Run Everyday
⌨️ (1:30:17) Automate The News - Convert py to exe
⌨️ (1:37:18) Automate The News - Schedule Python Script with crontab (macOS)
⌨️ (1:42:16) Project #3 - Automate Excel Report - Create a Pivot Table with Python
⌨️ (1:49:42) Automate Excel Report - Add a Bar Chart
⌨️ (2:05:02) Automate Excel Report - Write Excel Formulas with Python
⌨️ (2:19:18) Automate Excel Report - Format Cells
⌨️ (2:23:04) Automate Excel Report - Convert Pivot Table to Excel Report
⌨️ (2:25:32) Automate Excel Report - Generate Excel Reports with One Click (py to exe)
⌨️ (2:33:22) Project #4 - Automate WhatsApp

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Caw Yarson
topLevelComment.text: Thanks for this! I have very modest Python skills, but they've already helped me land a good job! During the interview process I explained "I used Python to help automate and expedite daily tasks, but I'm not a software developer and have  never been payed by an employer specifically to use Python." They appreciated my honesty and that I use modern languages as tools for workplace efficiency, now I'm earning more than I ever have before and am I hopeful that in the years to come I can continue to expand my skillset and value in the workplace!

topLevelComment.author: Michael Vilain
topLevelComment.text: This is incomplete. It lacks a README to describe how to setup an environment you can run these examples. It assumes all the Python libraries needed to do these exercises are already installed and that the student knows how to install them. 1st video uses  jupyter-lab notebook but says nothing on how to install it. 2nd video uses a traditional editor with code completion but no mention as to which one. I'll review the other exercises and send you mods I made to your repo that I forked.

replies.author: Arthur_P_Dent

replies.author: Michael Vilain
replies.text: @baya I know how to install them into the system, but IntelliJ seems to be somewhat confused about using virtual environments. I can install and configure one and use that as my profile for running and debugging code. BUT IntelliJ says the library isn't installed so it can't do code completion. Running and debugging works but you don't get the code completion unless you install the code via IntelliJ.

topLevelComment.author: Chris
topLevelComment.text:
In the end it doesn't matter what Python can do, VBA is used anyway.
In our company, we export a lot of data, mostly in CSV and tdms format.

And the only thing that can really do everything is VBA.

You can create small buttons in Excel itself.
When a file is opened, I click on it and VBA evaluates all the data in one second.

With Python you first need admin rights to install for example anaconda, also a free firewall to get the packages.

You always need two programs in parallel.

Matplotlotlib and plotly also lack many functions etc... 

With VBA I can read out whole folders from Excel very easily and write them into a prefabricated dashboard.

So far there is no alternative to VBA for everyday use.

replies.author: ML
replies.text: @Chris Well said.

replies.author: Chris
replies.text:
@Dominik Prager ​   My comment can also be misunderstood. 
Of course it's not about badmouthing the video or its content, this video is more for people who mainly work with Python and just to show the possibilities to interact with Excel a bit. 

I just noticed that in practice many people try to replace VBA with Python, because there are courses with "Automate Boring Stuff with Python". 

I don't really like VBA, but I also want to prevent people from spending a lot of time in Python because they think they can automate Excel work relatively well.

If Python was somehow integrated into Excel, it would be a great thing. And I hope there is some kind of programming language that you can connect everything with, so web scraping, databases, Excel etc. With which you can create protocols, reports, statistics, dashboards, websites, etc. from data in a completely automated way. 

I speak only from experience, I have been working in the automotive industry in development for many years. We also use a lot of Matlab, Labview and Altair software, but most of all Excel. 

Even for many tasks for which you actually need a real database software or for tasks for which Excel is not suitable at all.

That's wrong, but it's like that in practice at almost all large companies, unfortunately.

That's why the comment was important to me, so that no false expectations are placed on such videos by people who may want to use Python only as an additional secondary tool.

replies.author: Fernando Bedoya
replies.text: vba is for office people

replies.author: Dominik Prager
replies.text:
Read the video description. It doesn't say "Huge data extraction tutorial". Now to counterpoint - VBA is niche and generally not useful language to learn, and it's "Office-centric". The point of the tutorial was to showcase Python's universality because of how many people know and currently learn the language. It's simply more popular and versatile. The argument about admin rights is also very irrelevant, since you used the Excel example - because whole Microsoft Office basically 'plagues' your system, along with Windows, so, no, you actually end up needing less software in the case of Python, since it doesn't restrict you with any specific system. You can also implement your own functions if you need them, which results in being sort of lightweight and not messy. Syntax is also simpler.

One point VBA has is the speed, it really is fast, but that doesn't mean it's gonna be suitable forever. VBA has no real future. It's not flexible. It's gonna die out because it clings onto Microsoft's support. Anything you can do in VBA can be done in Python. Literally anything. Also, Python's getting quicker and quicker, the times when it was slower than VBA, are long gone.

 
Why learn so many useless commands when you can just create them with a few clean simple lines of code that are very portable? With a great package manager,  good documentation and amazing community, VBA can't be compared to the future - which is Python.

VBA is used only because of old habits. There is no other reason in 2022.

Also there are many more great languages other than Python, which are still better than the old VBA.
